com.pb.sawdust.util.collections

Interface InjectiveMap<K,V>

  • Type Parameters:
    K - The type of the keys held by this map.
    V - The type of the values held by this map.
    All Superinterfaces:
    java.util.Map<K,V>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    GenericInjectiveMap, InjectiveBiEnumMap, InjectiveEnumHashMap, InjectiveEnumMap, InjectiveHashMap

    public interface InjectiveMap<K,V>
extends java.util.Map<K,V>
    An InjectiveMap is a map whose keys map to unique values. More specifically, if a key, k, in a given map maps to a value, v, then another key in the same map, k', can map to any object except v. Another way of defining the injective map is that its keys and values each belong to a set. Mathematically speaking, a standard java.util.Map can map many keys to one value, making it surjective, whereas this interface, which only allows one key to any one value, is injective (hence the name).

    Because of the restrictions desribed above, adding a new key-value pair into a map which already contains the map causes a potential dilemma: if the pair is added, then the previously existing value, and hence its key, must be removed, or, alternatively, the pair could not be added, preserving the already existing key-value mapping. While map instances allow a previously existing key-value pair to be replaced, allowing a key to be removed (dissappear) during a put operation would be unexpected and a potential source of bugs. Thus, the put methods (and its derivatives) should throw an exception if the given value already exists. To allow the alternative behavior (remove the existing key-value pair), the forcePut and forcePutAll methods are added in this interface.

    • Method Detail

      • values

        java.util.Set<V> values()
        Get the values contained in this mapping. As the map is injective, the values are restricted to be in a set (as opposed to a collection, in the parent Map interface).
        Specified by:
        values in interface java.util.Map<K,V>
        Returns:
        the set of values contained in this map.

      • inverse

        InjectiveMap<V,K> inverse()
        Get the inverse of this map. This inverse will contain as values all of the keys in this map, and as keys all of those keys' respective values. Because the map is injective, the inverse mapping is guaranteed to exist.
        Returns:
        the inverse injective map of this map.

      • put

        V put(K key,
    V value)
        Because putting an already existing value would possibly force the removal of a key, such a method invoacation will cause an exception to be thrown. To get around this restriction, use the forcePut(K,V) method.
        Specified by:
        put in interface java.util.Map<K,V>
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the specified value already exists in the map.

      • forcePut

        V forcePut(K key,
         V value)
        Associate a given key with a given value. This method will always ensure that the specified key-value pair exists in map after this method's execution. This means that, in the case that the value is already used in the map, another map key will be removed silently. To prevent such behavior, use the put(K,V) method.
        Parameters:
        key - The key to associate with the value.
        value - The value to associate with the key.
        Returns:
        the previous value associated with key, or null if none existed.

      • getKey

        K getKey(V value)
        Get the key associated with a particular value in this map.
        Parameters:
        value - The value in question.
        Returns:
        the key associated with value.

      • removeValue

        K removeValue(java.lang.Object value)
        Remove this value, as well as its associated key, from this map.
        Parameters:
        value - The value to remove from this mapping.
        Returns:
        the key associated with value which was removed from this map.

      • putAll

        void putAll(java.util.Map<? extends K,? extends V> m)
        Because putting an already existing value would possibly force the removal of a key, such a method invoacation will cause an exception to be thrown. To get around this restriction, use the forcePutAll(Map) method.
        Specified by:
        putAll in interface java.util.Map<K,V>
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if one of the values in m already exists in the map.

      • forcePutAll

        void forcePutAll(java.util.Map<? extends K,? extends V> m)
        Put all of the mappings in a specified map into this map. If a give value already exists in thsi map, the current key-value pair will be removed before the map is updated. This final state of this map may thus be affected by the iteration order of m's mappings.
        Parameters:
        m - The map containging the mappings to put in this map.
